DOC.HEAD: Third American Civilian Reported Dead in Panama
EDs: SUBS 3rd graf: ``Dragseth was,'' to CORRECT last name of earlier victim from Helen to Helin
DOC.TEXT: The remains of an American teacher were discovered in Panama on Friday, and his daughter blamed Panamanians for his death. The American _ the third U.S. civilian to die since the conflict began _ was identified by his daughter as Raymond Dragseth, a teacher at the Panama Canal College, a Defense Department facility. Dragseth was reported to be the uncle of Richard Paul, a Defense Department dependent who was killed a week ago. An American who was working in Panama as a school teacher, Candy Helin, was killed shortly after the invasion began. The Pentagon has said previously that 23 servicemen have died since the Dec. 20 U.S. military intervention in Panama. Carolyn Dragseth, appearing at a news conference from Panama broadcast by CNN, blamed Panamanians for the abduction of her father, saying ``They just took my father _ I don't know why.'' ``They came here looking for Americans,'' she said. CNN said Raymond Dragseth was abducted from the family's apartment several hours after the American invasion began. ``They just took my father. I don't know why. There's no apparent reason why my father should have died.'' CNN said that Dragseth's wife told them she had tried to convince the Panamanians who abducted her husband that he was European. When asked whether her family had been contacted by the U.S. Embassy, Carolyn Dragseth said, ``They've been keeping in touch with us, especially since we, my family, located the body.'' The Pentagon said the remains of ``an individual'' have been recovered and once autopsy and identification efforts are complete additional details will be provided. At the State Department, an official said U.S. authorities were informed that Panamanian officials are in the process of exhuming a person whose description would fit that of a private American citizen. The official had no additional information.
